newsitem.title: USA: FORD POSTS RECORD Q2 PROFITS OF $2.53 BILLION.
newsitem.headline: FORD POSTS RECORD Q2 PROFITS OF $2.53 BILLION.

text.p: Ford Motor Co. said Wednesday its second-quarter profits jumped 33 percent to $2.53 billion, an all-time quarterly record.
The No. 2 U.S. automaker credited its performance to reduced automotive operating costs and the introduction of several new, redesigned cars and trucks.

Ford earned $2.06 on a per-share basis, beating the Wall Street analyst consensus estimate of $1.82, as reported by First Call Corp. A year ago, Ford posted profits of $1.90 billion, or $1.56 a share.
Worldwide sales and revenues were $40.3 billion, compared with $39 billion a year earlier.

Included in the latest results was a gain of $100 million reflecting a gain from the initial public offering of Hertz Corp. and a charge for closing several plants and the sale of Ford's heavy truck business to Freightliner.

Net income from Ford's worldwide automotive operations rose to $1.74 billion from $1.10 billion. The increase reflected strong profits in Ford's core U.S. automotive operations, which nearly doubled to $1.19 billion from $697 million.

"We're pleased to see automotive earnings continuing to improve," Ford Chairman Alex Trotman said in a statement. But he warned that more efforts were needed in Europe before the automaker will be able to achieve its long-term objectives. REUTER 161311 GMT jul 97
